per round.  (We use plain integers for clarity.)

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sympy as sp
from mpl_toolkits.mplot3d import Axes3D   


def bits(i, n):
    "Return i as an n-bit *list* (big-endian)."
    return list(map(int, format(i, f'0{n}b')))

def bits_reverse(i, n):
    "Little-endian version (least-significant bit first)."
    return bits(i, n)[::-1]

def eq_tilde(bits_i, u_vector):
    result=1
    for bit,u in zip(bits_i,u_vector):
        result *= (1-bit)*(1-u) + bit*u
    return result

def bits_of(i: int, n: int = 3):
    """Return the n-bit little-endian tuple of i (e.g. 5 ‚Üí (1,0,1))."""
    return tuple((i >> j) & 1 for j in range(n))

f_vec = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8]               # f(0,0,0) ‚Ä¶ f(1,1,1)
print("evaluations= ", f_vec)

n = 3
X0, X1, X2 = sp.symbols(f"x0:{n}")   # good
X = (X0, X1, X2)              # (X0, X1, X2)

f_tilde = sum(coeff * eq_tilde(bits(i, n), X)
              for i, coeff in enumerate(f_vec))


N = len(f_vec)

print("MLE polynomial in evaluation form:\n")
for i in range(N):
    term = eq_tilde(bits(i, n), X)
    print(f"a[{i}] = {f_vec[i]} => term = {f_vec[i]}*({term})")

print("\nExpanded polynomial:")
sp.pretty_print(sp.expand(f_tilde))

coords  = [bits_of(i, 3) for i in range(8)]   

# 3-D scatter plot
fig = plt.figure()
ax  = fig.add_subplot(111, projection='3d')
xs, ys, zs = zip(*coords)

ax.scatter(xs, ys, zs, s=60)

# annotate each vertex with its f-value
for (x0, x1, x2), val in zip(coords, f_vec):
    ax.text(x0, x1, x2, f"{val}", fontsize=10, ha='center')

ax.set_xlabel("X‚ÇÄ")
ax.set_ylabel("X‚ÇÅ")
ax.set_zlabel("X‚ÇÇ")
ax.set_title("Evaluation vector  f  on {0,1}¬≥")

plt.show()

# first-round h‚ÇÅ(X) polynomial

# Even half  (X‚ÇÄ = 0)
g1_0 = sum(f_vec[idx] for idx in range(8) if bits_of(idx)[0] == 0)
# Odd  half  (X‚ÇÄ = 1)
g1_1 = sum(f_vec[idx] for idx in range(8) if bits_of(idx)[0] == 1)

# h‚ÇÅ(X) = a + b¬∑X
a = g1_0
b = g1_1 - g1_0

print("\n‚îÄ‚îÄ First-round Sumcheck polynomial  h‚ÇÅ(X) ‚îÄ‚îÄ")
print(f"h‚ÇÅ(X) = {a}  +  {b}¬∑X")
print(f"h‚ÇÅ(0) = {a}        (even-half sum)")
print(f"h‚ÇÅ(1) = {a + b}    (odd-half  sum)")
print(f"h‚ÇÅ(2) = {a + 2*b}  (third evaluation sent to the verifier)")

import random
random.seed(int(12345))        # deterministic for the demo

# verifier samples Œ±‚ÇÄ
alpha0 = random.randint(2, 9)
print(f"Verifier samples  Œ±‚ÇÄ = {alpha0}")

# fold the vector:  f¬π(x‚ÇÅ,x‚ÇÇ) = f(Œ±‚ÇÄ, x‚ÇÅ, x‚ÇÇ) 
# even half  = indices where X‚ÇÄ = 0   (0,1,2,3)
# odd  half  = indices where X‚ÇÄ = 1   (4,5,6,7)
f_even = f_vec[0:4]
f_odd  = f_vec[4:8]

f_fold = [(1 - alpha0) * e + alpha0 * o     # (1-Œ±)¬∑even + Œ±¬∑odd
          for e, o in zip(f_even, f_odd)]

print("\nFolded 4-point vector  f¬π  on the (X‚ÇÅ,X‚ÇÇ) plane:")
for idx, val in enumerate(f_fold):
    print(f"  ({bits_of(idx,2)[0]}, {bits_of(idx,2)[1]})  ‚Üí  {val}")

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Arrange f_fold = [f(0,0), f(1,0), f(0,1), f(1,1)] into a 2-by-2 matrix
grid = np.array([[f_fold[0], f_fold[1]],
                 [f_fold[2], f_fold[3]]])

fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(4, 4))
im = ax.imshow(grid,
               cmap="Blues",
               origin="lower",            # (0,0) in the lower-left corner
               extent=[-0.5, 1.5, -0.5, 1.5],
               vmin=grid.min(), vmax=grid.max())

# Annotate each cell with its numeric value
for (i, j), val in np.ndenumerate(grid):
    ax.text(j, i, f"{val:.0f}",
            ha="center", va="center", color="black", fontsize=14)

ax.set_xticks([0, 1])
ax.set_yticks([0, 1])
ax.set_xlabel("X‚ÇÅ")
ax.set_ylabel("X‚ÇÇ")
ax.set_title("Folded function  $f^{(1)}$  after Round 1")

plt.colorbar(im, shrink=0.75, label="value")
plt.show()

#  Cheating prover with *same* total sum  S  but different vector
import random, math

# Choose a fake vector with the same sum 
S_real = sum(f_vec)                        # 36 for [1‚Ä¶8]

print("Honest vector :", f_vec)
n = 3
X = sp.symbols(f'X0:{n}')                       # (X0, X1, X2)
f_tilde = sum(coeff * eq_tilde(bits(i, n), X)
              for i, coeff in enumerate(f_vec))

# 2. Evaluate it at the verifier‚Äôs random challenges
poly_val = f_tilde.subs({X[0]: alpha0,
                         X[1]: alpha1,
                         X[2]: alpha2})

print("Expanded polynomial:")
sp.pretty_print(sp.expand(f_tilde))
print("\n")
f_fake_same_sum = list(reversed(f_vec))    # [8,7,6,5,4,3,2,1]
delta = sum(f_fake_same_sum) - S_real      # here 36 - 36 = 0



assert sum(f_fake_same_sum) == S_real and f_fake_same_sum != f_vec

print("Fake vector   :", f_fake_same_sum, "(same sum, different values)")

fake_tilde = sum(coeff * eq_tilde(bits(i, n), X)
              for i, coeff in enumerate(f_fake_same_sum))

# Evaluate it at the verifier‚Äôs random challenges
poly_val = fake_tilde.subs({X[0]: alpha0,
                         X[1]: alpha1,
                         X[2]: alpha2})

print("Expanded polynomial:")
sp.pretty_print(sp.expand(fake_tilde))
print("\n")


print("Total sum S   :", S_real, "\n")

def line_triplet(v0, v1):
    return (v0, v1, v0 + 2*(v1 - v0))

def sumcheck_transcript(vec, Œ±0, Œ±1):
    g1_0, g1_1 = sum(vec[:4]), sum(vec[4:])
    h1 = line_triplet(g1_0, g1_1)

    even, odd = vec[:4], vec[4:]
    f_fold = [(1-Œ±0)*e + Œ±0*o for e,o in zip(even, odd)]

    g2_0, g2_1 = f_fold[0]+f_fold[1], f_fold[2]+f_fold[3]
    h2 = line_triplet(g2_0, g2_1)

    even2, odd2 = f_fold[:2], f_fold[2:]
    f_fold2 = [(1-Œ±1)*e + Œ±1*o for e,o in zip(even2, odd2)]

    g3_0, g3_1 = f_fold2
    h3 = line_triplet(g3_0, g3_1)

    Œ±2   = random.randint(0, 1)     
    leaf = eval_line(h3, Œ±2) 
    return h1, h2, h3, Œ±2, leaf

def eval_line(h, x):
    return h[0] + (h[1]-h[0])*x

def verifier_accepts(h1,h2,h3, Œ±0,Œ±1,Œ±2, leaf, S):
    """Return True iff all 4 Sumcheck equalities hold."""
    return (
        math.isclose(h1[0]+h1[1], S) and
        math.isclose(h2[0]+h2[1], eval_line(h1, Œ±0)) and
        math.isclose(h3[0]+h3[1], eval_line(h2, Œ±1)) and
        math.isclose(leaf,          h3[Œ±2])
    )

h1_h, h2_h, h3_h, Œ±2_h, leaf_h = sumcheck_transcript(f_vec,  alpha0, alpha1)
h1_c, h2_c, h3_c, Œ±2_c, leaf_c = sumcheck_transcript(f_fake_same_sum,
                                                     alpha0, alpha1)

print("Verifier challenges: Œ±0 =", alpha0, "Œ±1 =", alpha1, "Œ±2 =", Œ±2_c)
print("Honest leaf =", leaf_h, "   Fake leaf =", leaf_c, "\n")

def poly_str(h):
    """Return 'a + b¬∑X' string for a degree-1 poly given (h0,h1, _)."""
    a, b = h[0], h[1] - h[0]
    return f"{a:.1f}  +  {b:.1f}¬∑X"

def run_and_explain(tag, h1,h2,h3, Œ±0,Œ±1,Œ±2, leaf, S):
    print(f"\n===== Verifier run on {tag} transcript =====")
    print("Prover‚Äôs messages:")
    print("  h‚ÇÅ values =", h1, "  ‚áí  h‚ÇÅ(X) =", poly_str(h1))
    print("  h‚ÇÇ values =", h2, "  ‚áí  h‚ÇÇ(X) =", poly_str(h2))
    print("  h‚ÇÉ values =", h3, "  ‚áí  h‚ÇÉ(X) =", poly_str(h3))
    print("  leaf =", leaf, "\n")

    # --- algebraic checks ----------------------------------
    check1 = math.isclose(h1[0] + h1[1], S)
    check2 = math.isclose(h2[0] + h2[1], eval_line(h1, Œ±0))
    check3 = math.isclose(h3[0] + h3[1], eval_line(h2, Œ±1))
    check4 = math.isclose(leaf        , h3[Œ±2])

    print(f"‚ë†  h‚ÇÅ(0)+h‚ÇÅ(1) = {h1[0]+h1[1]:>8}    vs  S = {S:<8}        ‚Üí {check1}")
    print(f"‚ë°  h‚ÇÇ(0)+h‚ÇÇ(1) = {h2[0]+h2[1]:>8}    vs  h‚ÇÅ(Œ±‚ÇÄ) = {eval_line(h1,Œ±0):<8}  ‚Üí {check2}")
    print(f"‚ë¢  h‚ÇÉ(0)+h‚ÇÉ(1) = {h3[0]+h3[1]:>8}    vs  h‚ÇÇ(Œ±‚ÇÅ) = {eval_line(h2,Œ±1):<8}  ‚Üí {check3}")
    print(f"‚ë£  leaf        = {leaf:>8}    vs  h‚ÇÉ(Œ±‚ÇÇ) = {h3[Œ±2]:<8}       ‚Üí {check4}")

    all_pass = check1 and check2 and check3 and check4
    print("Result:", "‚úî PASSED" if all_pass else "‚úñ REJECTED")
    return all_pass

ok_honest = run_and_explain("HONEST",
                            h1_h,h2_h,h3_h,
                            alpha0,alpha1,Œ±2_h,
                            leaf_h, S_real)

ok_fake   = run_and_explain("FAKE  ",
                            h1_c,h2_c,h3_c,
                            alpha0,alpha1,Œ±2_c,
                            leaf_c, S_real)   
print("Verifier result on HONEST transcript :", ok_honest)
print("Verifier result on FAKE   transcript :", ok_fake, "\n")

def eval_mle(evals, u):
    return sum(e*eq_tilde(bits_of(i,3), u) for i,e in enumerate(evals))

u_test = (0,0,0)
print(f"At point u = {u_test}:")
print("  honest fÃÉ(u) =", eval_mle(f_vec, u_test))
print("  fake   fÃÉ(u) =", eval_mle(f_fake_same_sum, u_test),
      "‚Üê different but still passed Sumcheck!")

  leaf = -28

‚ë°  h‚ÇÇ(0)+h‚ÇÇ(1) =     -102    vs  h‚ÇÅ(Œ±‚ÇÄ) = -102      ‚Üí True
‚ë¢  h‚ÇÉ(0)+h‚ÇÉ(1) =      -57    vs  h‚ÇÇ(Œ±‚ÇÅ) = -57       ‚Üí True
‚ë£  leaf        =      -28    vs  h‚ÇÉ(Œ±‚ÇÇ) = -28            ‚Üí True
Result: ‚úî PASSED
Verifier result on HONEST transcript : True
Verifier result on FAKE   transcript : True 

At point u = (0, 0, 0):
  honest fÃÉ(u) = 1
  fake   fÃÉ(u) = 8 ‚Üê different but still passed Sumcheck!

children.value: Sumcheck only checks algebra; the verifier never sees the
. A prover can swap in a different vector
after learning the challenges and still pass all four checks.

digest together with the claimed
value
Cheater ‚Üí digest mismatch (or wrong value) ‚Üí verifier rejects.
The tiny SHA-256 PCS below demonstrates this:

it succeeds on the honest vector and fails on the
fake one.

import hashlib, json, math

def _canonical(evals):
    return [int(x) for x in evals]

def pcs_commit(evals):
    blob = json.dumps(_canonical(evals), separators=(",", ":")).encode()
    return hashlib.sha256(blob).hexdigest()

def pcs_open(evals, point, claimed_val, commitment, *, verbose=True):
    """
    Return (all_ok, digest_ok, value_ok)
    ‚Ä¢ If verbose=True, print a one-line explanation whenever something fails.
    """
    digest_ok = (pcs_commit(evals) == commitment)
    if verbose and not digest_ok:
        print("[PCS] digest mismatch "
              f"(got {commitment[:12]}‚Ä¶, expected {pcs_commit(evals)[:12]}‚Ä¶ )")

    poly_val = sum(int(e) * eq_tilde(bits_of(i, 3), point)
                   for i, e in enumerate(evals))
    value_ok = math.isclose(poly_val, claimed_val)
    if verbose and digest_ok and not value_ok:
        print("[PCS] value mismatch "
              f"(claimed {claimed_val}, recomputed {poly_val})")

    if verbose and digest_ok and value_ok:
        print("[PCS] ‚úî digest & value both correct")

    return digest_ok and value_ok, digest_ok, value_ok

print(" Honest evaluation vector  :", f_vec)
print(" Fake   evaluation vector  :", f_fake_same_sum, "(same Œ£, different order)\n")

commit_honest = pcs_commit(f_vec)
commit_fake   = pcs_commit(f_fake_same_sum)
print("Honest commitment digest :", commit_honest)
print("Fake   commitment digest :", commit_fake)
print("   Digests equal ? ", commit_honest == commit_fake, "\n")

query_pt = (alpha0, alpha1, Œ±2_h)               
leaf_h   = eval_mle(f_vec , query_pt)          
leaf_f   = eval_mle(f_fake_same_sum, query_pt)        


ok_honest, dig_honest, val_honest = pcs_open(f_vec , query_pt, leaf_h, commit_honest)
ok_fake  , dig_fake , val_fake  = pcs_open(f_fake_same_sum, query_pt, leaf_f, commit_honest)

print("PCS-open on HONEST data :", ok_honest)
print("PCS-open on FAKE  data  :", ok_fake, "\n",
      "‚Üê fails (digest mismatch)")

children.html: f~(X)=‚àëi‚àà0,1nai,Ei(X),Ei(X)=‚àèj=0n‚àí1(bits(i)j,Xj+(1‚àíbits(i)j)(1‚àíXj))\tilde{f}(\mathbf{X}) = \sum_{i \in {0,1}^n} a_i,E_i(\mathbf{X}), \quad E_i(\mathbf{X}) = \prod_{j=0}^{n-1} \left( \mathrm{bits}(i)_j,X_j + (1 - \mathrm{bits}(i)_j)(1 - X_j) \right)f~‚Äã(X)=i‚àà0,1n‚àë‚Äãai‚Äã,Ei‚Äã(X),Ei‚Äã(X)=j=0‚àèn‚àí1‚Äã(bits(i)j‚Äã,Xj‚Äã+(1‚àíbits(i)j‚Äã)(1‚àíXj‚Äã))

children.value: a single point-evaluation can be rewritten as an inner product:

children.html: f~(u)=‚àëi‚àà0,1nai,Ei(u)‚èü=,eq(u,i)=‚ü®(a0,‚Ä¶,a2n‚àí1)‚èüfvec,(eq(u,0),‚Ä¶,eq(u,2n‚àí1))‚èüwvec‚ü©\boxed{ \tilde{f}(\mathbf{u}) = \sum_{i \in {0,1}^n} a_i,\underbrace{E_i(\mathbf{u})}{=,eq(\mathbf{u}, i)} = \left\langle \underbrace{(a_0, \dots, a{2^n - 1})}{f{\text{vec}}}, \underbrace{(eq(\mathbf{u}, 0), \dots, eq(\mathbf{u}, 2^n - 1))}{w{\text{vec}}} \right\rangle }f~‚Äã(u)=i‚àà0,1n‚àë‚Äãai‚Äã,Ei‚Äã(u)‚Äã=,eq(u,i)=‚ü®(a0‚Äã,‚Ä¶,a2n‚àí1)‚Äãfvec,(eq(u,0),‚Ä¶,eq(u,2n‚àí1))‚Äãwvec‚ü©‚Äã

‚Ä¢	Left-hand side ‚Äî the usual ‚Äúplug-and-chug‚Äù evaluation.
‚Ä¢	Right-hand side ‚Äî a length-$2^n$ sum, exactly the form the Sumcheck protocol can certify.
In the notebook below we will:

u=(Œ±0,Œ±1,Œ±2)\mathbf{u} = (\alpha_0, \alpha_1, \alpha_2)u=(Œ±0‚Äã,Œ±1‚Äã,Œ±2‚Äã)
‚ü®fvec,wvec‚ü©\langle f_{\text{vec}}, w_{\text{vec}} \rangle‚ü®fvec‚Äã,wvec‚Äã‚ü©

children.value: show it equals the direct polynomial value computed earlier.
That makes the algebraic bridge between an MLE evaluation and a Sumcheck sum concrete.

# Fact 1 : a single evaluation is an inner product 
u_point = (alpha0, alpha1, alpha2)                     

try:
    _ = poly_honest      
except NameError:
    poly_honest = sp.expand(sum(
        int(f) * eq_tilde(bits_of(i, 3), X)     
        for i, f in enumerate(f_vec)
    ))

print("\nFull multilinear extension  fÃÉ(X‚ÇÄ,X‚ÇÅ,X‚ÇÇ):")
sp.pretty_print(poly_honest)


# Build equality-function vector  w  (length 8)
w_vec = [eq_tilde(bits_of(i, 3), u_point) for i in range(8)]


print("Verifier‚Äôs point  u =", u_point, "\n")
print(" i   bits       f_vec[i]      w[i]   contribution  f[i]¬∑w[i]")
print("‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ  ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ      ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ     ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ  ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ")

contribs = []
for i, (f, w) in enumerate(zip(f_vec, w_vec)):
    c = f * w
    contribs.append(c)
    print(f"{i:2}   {bits_of(i,3)}     {f:>2}        {w:>5}        {c:>6}")

inner_prod = sum(contribs)
poly_val   = eval_mle(f_vec, u_point)                  # direct evaluation

print("\nŒ£ contributions =", inner_prod)
print("Direct polynomial value fÃÉ(u) =", poly_val)

assert inner_prod == poly_val
print("\n‚úî  fÃÉ(u) equals the length-8 inner product ‚ü®f_vec , w_vec‚ü©.")

children.value: At every round both protocols take a length-

children.html: 2m2m2m
fold(Œ±)=(1‚àíŒ±)‚Äâeven+Œ±‚Äâodd\texttt{fold}(\alpha) = (1 - \alpha)\,\texttt{even} + \alpha\,\texttt{odd}fold(Œ±)=(1‚àíŒ±)even+Œ±odd

children.value: uses it to reduce the multilinear inner-product dimension.
map to reduce a Reed‚ÄìSolomon codeword.
Below we fold the honest evaluation vector two ways:
with the hand-written Sumcheck comprehension already in the notebook,
They land on exactly the same 4-entry vector, confirming the equivalence.

'''
The actual folding from the implementation itself : 

            # fold f_code
            f_code_folded = [(Field(1)-alpha) * (f_code[2*j] + f_code[2*j+1]) / 2 
                      + alpha * (f_code[2*j] - f_code[2*j+1]) / (2 * coset * twiddles[j]) 
                      for j in range(len(f_code)//2)]
'''

def fri_split_fold(even, odd, alpha):
    """
    Return (1-alpha)*even + alpha*odd   element-wise, exactly what FRI
    does to halve a Reed‚ÄìSolomon codeword.  Works for plain lists of
    field elements as used in this demo.
    """
    return [(1 - alpha) * e + alpha * o for e, o in zip(even, odd)]


even = f_vec[:4]          # indices 000,001,010,011  (X‚ÇÄ=0)
odd  = f_vec[4:]          # indices 100,101,110,111  (X‚ÇÄ=1)
Œ±    = alpha0             # verifier‚Äôs first challenge

print("even =", even)
print("odd  =", odd)
print("Œ± =", Œ±, "\n")

# Sumcheck‚Äôs explicit comprehension
sumcheck_fold = [(1-Œ±)*e + Œ±*o for e, o in zip(even, odd)]
print("Sumcheck fold :", sumcheck_fold)

# FRI‚Äôs comprehension
pcs = BASEFOLD_RS_PCS(MerkleTree, debug=0)
fri_fold = fri_split_fold(even, odd, Œ±)  
print("FRI      fold :", fri_fold, "\n")

assert sumcheck_fold == fri_fold
print("‚úî  Identical output ‚áí both protocols share the very same linear map.")

**C‚ÇÄ**"]):::b A0 -->|encode| A1 -->|Merkle| A2 subgraph G1[ Prover side ] A0;A1;A2 end %% Shared loop B0(("k = 3 rounds")):::s %% Round boxes R1["Round 0

# Basefold PCS demo  (n = 3, f = [1‚Ä¶8]) 
import basefold_rs_pcs as pcs_mod              
from merlin.merlin_transcript import MerlinTranscript
from utils import inner_product               

Field            = pcs_mod.Field              
MerkleTree       = pcs_mod.MerkleTree
BASEFOLD_RS_PCS  = pcs_mod.BASEFOLD_RS_PCS
MLEPolynomial    = pcs_mod.MLEPolynomial

# public instance 
evals   = [Field(i) for i in range(1, 9)]          # f = [1,2,3,4,5,6,7,8]
u_point = [Field(alpha0), Field(alpha1), Field(alpha2)]   # the same Œ±‚Äôs

MLEPolynomial.set_field_type(Field)
f_mle = MLEPolynomial(evals, 3)

# v = f(u)
eq_vec = MLEPolynomial.eqs_over_hypercube(u_point)
v_true = inner_product(evals, eq_vec, Field.zero())
assert f_mle.evaluate(u_point) == v_true

print(f"Public claim :  f({u_point}) = v = {v_true}\n")

# set-up prover / verifier objects 
pcs = BASEFOLD_RS_PCS(MerkleTree, debug=2)     
pcs.security_bits = 32 
tr  = MerlinTranscript(b"basefold-rs-demo")

# commitment
f_cm = pcs.commit(f_mle)
print("Commitment root :", f_cm.cm, "‚Ä¶\n")

# prover produces argument 
print("üïê  Prover: generating proof ‚Ä¶")
v_proved, argument = pcs.prove_eval(f_cm, f_mle, u_point, tr.fork(b"prove"))
print("‚ÑπÔ∏è  Proof generated.\n")
assert v_proved == v_true

# verifier checks
print("üïê  Verifier: checking proof ‚Ä¶")
ok = pcs.verify_eval(f_cm, u_point, v_true, argument, tr.fork(b"verify"))
print("‚úÖ  Proof verified =", ok)
